238.01   ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE.
   There is hereby established, in and for the Village, pursuant to the
authority vested in Council by Ohio R.C. 735.32, the office of Engineer of the
Village. The person appointed to such office shall be known as the Village
Engineer, or just the Engineer.
(Ord. 1963-16. Passed 4-2-63.)
238.02   QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Engineer shall be a professional engineer registered in the State.
(Ord. 1991-6. Passed 2-5-91.)
238.03   APPOINTMENT AND TERM.
   The Engineer shall be appointed by the Mayor and confirmed by Council for a
term of one year, subject, however, to the provisions of Section
260.01, which provides, inter alia, that the term of office of any full-time
appointed officer of the Village shall terminate not later than the first
Monday in February.
(Ord. 1963-16. Passed 4-2-63.)
238.04   DUTIES GENERALLY; AUTHORITY TO HIRE PERSONNEL.
   (a)   The Engineer shall supervise the improvement and repair of streets,
avenues, alleys, lands, lanes, squares, bridges, viaducts, sidewalks, sewers,
drains, ditches, culverts, streams and watercourses; supervise the lighting,
sprinkling and cleaning of all public places; and perform such other duties,
consistent with the aforementioned responsibilities, as Council requires. In
addition, he or she shall attend Council meetings or Planning Commission
meetings when requested by the Mayor or Council.
   (b)   The Engineer, in the performance of his or her responsibilities set
forth in subsection (a) hereof, shall have the authority, with the approval of
the Mayor, to hire Class B part-time assistants as set forth in Section
260.03, and for that purpose such Section
260.03 shall be construed to provide that either the Street Commissioner or the
Engineer, with the approval of the Mayor, shall have the authority to hire such
Class B part-time employees.
(Ord. 1963-16. Passed 4-2-63.)
238.05   PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS; PROGRESS REPORTS.
   (a)   The Engineer shall:
      (1)   Prepare and furnish to Council necessary plans, profiles,
specifications and estimates of cost for such public improvements as he or she
may be authorized by Council to prepare, and furnish to Council such other
professional engineering advice as it may request.
      (2)   Supervise and serve as the representative of the Village in the
execution of public improvements undertaken by Council pursuant to plans and
specifications prepared by him or her, and supervise the execution of other
public improvements when requested by Council.
      (3)   Upon request, make and deliver to Council reports of the progress
of improvements under his or her supervision, stating conditions of the same
together with any other matters of interest desired by Council.
      (4)   Assist and render such professional engineering advice to any
department of the Village, when requested by the Village officer in charge
thereof.
   (b)   All plans, specifications, profiles, estimates and other work products
of the Engineer for which he or she is compensated under the terms of this
chapter shall be the property of the Village, and all such property shall be
filed in the office of the Clerk.
(Ord. 1963-16. Passed 4-2-63.)
238.06   COMPENSATION.
   (a)   For the services set forth in Section
238.04(a), the Engineer shall be compensated at a rate to be determined from
time to time by Council. Such rate shall be payable in equal monthly payments
on the fifteenth day of each month for services rendered the preceding month.
   (b)   For the services set forth in Section
238.05(a), the Engineer shall be compensated at a rate to be determined from
time to time by Council. Such rate shall be payable monthly, on the fifteenth
day of each month, for services rendered the preceding month. The Engineer
shall submit to the Clerk, on the first day of each month, a report of the
number of hours worked by him or her in the previous month in rendering the
services set forth in Section
238.05, together with an analysis of services so rendered. Such report must be
countersigned by the Mayor.
(Adopting Ordinance)
   (c)   In the event a question should arise as to whether services rendered
by the Engineer are within the purview of Section
238.04(a) or 238.05(a), the matter shall be submitted to the Mayor, whose
decision shall be final and binding upon both the Engineer and the Village.
(Ord. 1963-16. Passed 4-2-63.)

   Appointment - see Ohio R.C. 735.31

240.01   ESTABLISHMENT OF OFFICE; APPOINTMENT AND TERM.
   There is hereby established, in and for the Village, the office of Street
Commissioner of the Village, such Commissioner to be appointed by the Mayor,
subject to confirmation by Council, for a term not to exceed one year.
240.02   DUTIES GENERALLY.
   Under the direction of Council and the Engineer, the Street Commissioner
shall supervise the improvement and repair of streets, avenues, alleys, lands,
lanes, squares, wards, landings, market houses, bridges, viaducts, sidewalks,
sewers, drains, ditches, culverts, ship channels, streams and watercourses. He
or she shall also supervise the lighting, sprinkling and cleaning of all public
places and shall perform such other duties, consistent with the nature of his
or her office, as Council requires.
240.03   MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR OF PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY.
   The Street Commissioner shall be responsible for the proper maintenance and
repair of roads, berms, ditches, culverts, signs, lighting, marking and
striping, cleaning, easements and drainage areas in the Village.
(Ord. 1968-8. Passed 3-19-68.)
240.04   SNOW AND ICE REMOVAL.
   The Street Commissioner shall be responsible for the prompt removal of snow
and ice, including spreading of salt and/or cinders (and for acquiring and
stockpiling adequate supplies of salt and cinders) on all Village roads. He or
she may delegate to the senior patrolman on duty the authority to call out snow
removal crews.
(Ord. 1968-8. Passed 3-19-68.)
240.05   PURCHASE OF MATERIALS AND TOOLS.
   The Street Commissioner shall be responsible for the purchase of necessary
materials and tools, such as stone, sand, tile, hand tools, paint, signs, etc.,
to assure the proper performance of his or her responsibilities within the
monetary limits authorized by Council and for the procurement and hiring of
adequate full and part-time emergency help to perform the duties of his or her
office.
(Ord. 1968-8. Passed 3-19-68.)
240.06   SUPERVISION OF SUBORDINATES.
   The Street Commissioner shall personally supervise all employees under his
or her responsibility for the quantity and quality of the work performed by the
employees and for on-the-job training, if necessary, of each employee and shall
be responsible for the proper maintenance and storage of all mobile equipment,
including trucks, tractors, backhoes and tools owned by the Village and used by
his or her employees.
(Ord. 1968-8. Passed 3-19-68.)
240.07   MISCELLANEOUS DUTIES.
   The Street Commissioner shall be responsible for the clearance of weeds,
snow and any other obstructions from around all fire hydrants in the Village
and for providing necessary manpower and equipment for the Chief of Police,
Recreation Director, Clerk, Engineer and Inspector of Buildings, when so
directed by the Mayor for such Village functions as trash removal and
maintenance of the recreation area and the Village Hall.
(Ord. 1968-8. Passed 3-19-68.)
240.08   COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The Street Commissioner salary shall be set in accordance with
Chapter 260 of these Codified Ordinances, and shall also include an hourly rate
for overtime as approved by the Mayor. The Street Commissioner shall be paid
bi-weekly during said term.
   (b)   The Street Commissioner shall not be entitled to health care,
prescriptive drug, dental or vision insurance.
   (c)   The Street Commissioner shall be entitled to the same vacation,
holiday, sick leave as those accorded certain employees pursuant to the
provisions of this
Chapter 260, provided, however, that when the Street Commissioner is also the
Inspector of Buildings, the basis of payment for such privileges shall be an
assumed regularly scheduled forty hours per week, eight hours per day, for the
combined offices.
(Ord. 1979-6. Passed 1-16-79; Res. 2011-47. Passed 12-29-11.)
240.09   ASSISTANT STREET COMMISSIONER.
   There is hereby established the office of Assistant Street Commissioner of
the Village. Such Assistant Street Commissioner shall be appointed by the Mayor
and the Street Commissioner, and the Assistant Street Commissioner shall be an
at-will employee. The Assistant Street Commissioner shall be compensated in
accordance with
Chapter 260 of the Codified Ordinances of the Village of Walton Hills, Ohio.
(Ord. 1979-45. Passed 6-19-79; Ord. 2006-5. Passed 2-7-05.)

Chapter 242 of these Codified Ordinances, the term "full-time officer(s)",

Chapter 260 of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 2010-12. Passed 5-18-10; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)

242.04   APPOINTMENT AND PROBATION OF PATROLMEN.
   (a)   (1)   Full-time and part-time Deputy Marshals, designated Patrolmen,
shall be employed in such numbers as Council shall from time to time determine.
Such Patrolmen are not required to be electors of the Village.
      (2)   The Police Chief, with the Mayor’s approval, is hereby authorized
to hire part-time Deputy Marshals, designated part-time police patrolmen, in
such number and for such working hours per week as may from time to time be
budgeted by Council.
(Adopting Ordinance; Ord. 2014-10. Passed 9-16-14.)
   (b)   The appointment of such Patrolmen shall be made by the Mayor, subject
to confirmation by Council, for a probationary period of 12 months or more of
continuous service, and no appointment shall be finally made until the
appointee has satisfactorily served his or her probationary period. At the end
of the probationary period, the Mayor shall transmit to Council a record of the
service of such appointee with the Mayor's recommendations thereon, and the
Mayor may, with the concurrence of Council, remove or finally appoint such
Patrolmen.
(Ord. 1982-27. Passed 5-4-82 ; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.05   DESIGNATION AND APPOINTMENT OF CAPTAIN.
   (a)    From the number of full-time Sergeants employed by the Village, and
the Lieutenant, if any, the designation and appointment of one such Sergeant or
Lieutenant to Captain is hereby authorized.
   (b)    No Sergeant shall be eligible for designation and appointment as a
Captain until he or she has served a total of five years as a full-time
Sergeant for the Village.
   (c)    The designation and appointment of one Sergeant or Lieutenant to
Captain shall be made by the Chief of Police, at his or her sole discretion and
election, subject to approval and confirmation by the Mayor and Council.
Vacancies in the grade of Captain shall be filled by appointment by the Chief
of Police, at his or her sole discretion and election, from those persons
determined to be eligible, which appointment shall be subject to approval and
confirmation by the Mayor and Council.
   (d)   The Captain shall serve as the Executive Officer to oversee the
operation of the Police Department in the absence of the Chief of Police, and
shall attend to all duties assigned by the Chief of Police, including Detective
Bureau duties, patrol duties, or administrative duties, if assigned.
   (e)   The position of Captain in the Police Department shall be an at-will
appointment, but shall not constitute an at-will employment position. The
Captain shall hold the position of Captain until retirement, resignation or
until removed by the Police Chief. If so removed by the Police Chief, he or she
shall be entitled, unless said removal shall have been for reasons which
constitute grounds for termination, to be placed back into the position/rank
held by him or her immediately prior to their appointment to Captain.
   (f)   The Police Captain's salary and benefits shall be set in accordance
with Chapter 260 of these Codified Ordinances, and shall also include an hourly
rate for overtime as approved by the Mayor. Overtime for the Police Captain
shall only be approved by the Mayor in the event that the overtime expense is
paid from grant monies or donations.
(Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12; Ord. 2013-5. Passed 2-19-13.)
242.051   DESIGNATION AND APPOINTMENT OF LIEUTENANT.
   (a)   From the number of full-time Sergeants authorized to be employed by
the Village, the designation and appointment of one such Sergeant to Lieutenant
is hereby authorized.
   (b)   No Sergeant shall be eligible for designation and appointment as a
Lieutenant until he or she has served a total of five years as a full-time
Sergeant for the Village.
   (c)   The designation and appointment of one Sergeant to Lieutenant shall be
made by the Chief of Police at his or her sole discretion and election, subject
to approval and confirmation by the Mayor and Council. Vacancies in the grade
of Lieutenant shall be filled by appointment by the Chief of Police at his or
her sole discretion and election from those persons determined to be eligible,
which appointment shall be subject to approval and confirmation by the Mayor
and Council.
   (d)   The Lieutenant shall be the first line supervisor of the Sergeants.
The Lieutenant may also be assigned Detective Bureau duties, patrol duties, or
administrative duties.
(Ord. 1998-15. Passed 12-15-98; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.06   DESIGNATION AND APPOINTMENT OF SERGEANTS.
   (a)   From the number of full-time Patrolmen authorized to be employed by
the Village, the designation and appointment of four such Patrolmen to Sergeant
is hereby authorized.
    (b)   No Patrolman shall be eligible for designation and appointment as a
Sergeant until he or she has served a total of five years as a full-time
Patrolman for the Village. In addition, eligibility for designation as Sergeant
shall be determined by promotional exam or from an existing promotional
eligibility list and shall be pursuant to the rules and regulations to be
promulgated by Council.
   (c)   The designation and appointment of up to four Patrolmen to Sergeant
shall be made by the Chief of Police, subject to confirmation by the Mayor and
Council. Eligibility for designation and appointment as Sergeant shall be
subject to the basic requirement set forth in subsection (b) hereof, and
vacancies in the grade of Sergeant shall be filled by appointment by the Chief
of Police from those persons determined to be eligible, which appointment shall
be subject to confirmation by the Mayor and Council.
   (d)   The assignment of one or more patrol officer(s), Sergeant(s),
Lieutenant or Captain to the Detective Bureau shall be made by the Chief of
Police as needed from time to time. The Detective Bureau shall be in charge of
investigations and overseeing the work of other senior officers during
investigations.
   (e)   At no time shall there be less than three full-time police Sergeants
serving the Police Department. The Chief of Police shall offer sufficient
promotional opportunity to maintain a staffing level of at least three full-
time Sergeants. The fourth Sergeant shall serve at the sole discretion of the
Chief of Police or the Mayor/Safety Director.
(Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.07   POWERS OF PATROLMEN.
   A Patrolman shall have the powers conferred upon police officers by law in
all incorporated villages of the State.
(Ord. 1973-15. Passed 7-17-73; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.08   SUPERVISION OF PATROLMEN.
   Patrolmen shall serve the Village under the direction of the Chief of
Police, who is the executive head, under the Mayor, of the Police Department of
the Village.
(Ord. 1973-15. Passed 7-17-73; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.09   WORK SCHEDULE OF PATROLMEN.
   A Patrolman, although on 24 hour call for police duty, shall be on regular
duty only during such hours of such days and for a total number of hours per
week as may be scheduled for him or her by the Chief of Police, or as the Mayor
shall schedule and direct.
(Ord. 1973-15. Passed 7-17-73 ; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.10   ADDITIONAL DUTIES FOR PATROLMEN.
   A Patrolman, in addition to police duties assigned to him or her, shall, to
the extent practicable, aid in the task of snow removal and road and other
maintenance in the Village when so directed by the Chief of Police upon request
of the Mayor or the Street Commissioner directed to the Chief of Police.
However, if such work is required during the schedule of "off duty" hours of a
full-time Patrolman, he or she shall receive compensation therefor in addition
to his or her regular compensation.
(Ord. 1973-15. Passed 7-17-73; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.11   LONGEVITY PAY FOR FULL-TIME OFFICERS.
   Full-time police officers shall, in addition to their base (regular) rate of
compensation, be paid a monthly longevity pay to be determined from time to
time by Council.
(Ord. 2007-26. Passed 7-3-07 ; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.12   HOLIDAYS FOR FULL-TIME OFFICERS.
   (a)   Each full-time police officer shall be entitled to receive
compensation at his or her regular rate of pay for eight hours for the
following legal holidays (or the day recognized as such): New Year's Day,
Martin Luther King Day, Washington-Lincoln Day (Presidents' Day), Easter,
Memorial Day, Independence Day, Labor Day, Veterans' Day, Thanksgiving Day and
Christmas Day.
   Any day declared to be a holiday by the Mayor and Council during the
effective period of this section shall be added to the existing holiday
schedule.
   Each full-time police officer shall be entitled to three personal days as
well as the officer's birthday following one year of employment as a full-time
police officer of the Village. An additional personal day shall be allowed for
the succeeding year for a police officer who works a full calendar year without
taking any sick leave.
   A full-time police officer shall have the option of scheduling Thanksgiving
and Christmas holiday as a personal day with the approval of the Police Chief.
No holidays or personal days may be carried over into the next year without the
permission of the Police Chief and the Mayor.
   (b)   A full-time police officer who works on a holiday shall receive, at
the option of the Police Chief, either:
      (1)   Eight hours of compensatory time off (as scheduled by the Chief);
or
      (2)   Pay at the regular rate, for such number of hours as such officer
works on such holiday, in addition to eight hours of holiday pay, except that,
a full-time police officer who is scheduled to work on Easter, Thanksgiving
Day, Christmas Day or New Year’s Day shall receive pay at the time and one-half
rate for such number of hours as such officer works on such holiday, in
addition to receiving eight hours of holiday pay.
   (c)   A part-time police officer who works on Easter, Thanksgiving Day,
Christmas Day or New Year’s Day shall receive pay at the time and one-half rate
for such number of hours as such officer works on such holiday.
(Ord. 1998-15. Passed 12-15-98; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2007-26.
Passed 7-3-07; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12; Ord. 2013-22. Passed 12-17-13.)
242.13   VACATIONS FOR FULL-TIME OFFICERS.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2013, all full-time police officers who have
completed one year of Village service or more as of December 31 of any given
year shall be entitled to vacation in the subsequent year based on the
following full years of service as of December 31:
      1 to 3 years of service - 80 hours of vacation;
      4 to 8 years of service - 120 hours of vacation;
      9 to 13 years of service - 160 hours of vacation;
      14 years of service or more - 200 hours of vacation.
   (b)   Any full-time police officer that has accumulated 19 years of service
or more to the Police Department as a full-time police officer as of January 1,
2013 shall be entitled to vacation in the subsequent year based on the
following years of service as of December 31:
      1 to 3 years of service - 80 hours of vacation;
      4 to 8 years of service - 120 hours of vacation;
      9 to 13 years of service - 160 hours of vacation;
      14 to 23 years of service - 200 hours of vacation;
      24 years of service or more - 240 hours of vacation.
   (c)   The first year of any full-time police officers employment shall be
construed to be that time period from the officer's date of hire to December 31
of the same year. Thereafter, each year shall be from January 1 to December 31.
   (d)   Vacation time earned during the first year of employment shall be
prorated, based on the amount of vacation contained in division (a) above to
reflect service time from the date of full-time employment to December 31 of
the first year. Vacation time earned during the final calendar year of full-
time employment shall be prorated, based on the amount of vacation contained in
divisions (a) and (b) above to reflect service time from January 1 to the final
date of full-time employment.
   (e)   Full-time police officers who have been employed by the Police
Department for more than one year may carry over a maximum of 40 hours vacation
credit to the next fiscal year. Excess vacation time over 40 hours shall be
paid as of the last full pay period in December of the current year, at the
then-effective hourly rate of pay for that police officer.
   (f)   A full-time police officer who is reemployed or rehired in the same
position by the Village upon retirement will not be paid for any earned and
unused accumulated vacation. The police officer will continue to accrue
vacation and retain his or her unused accumulated vacation time and continue to
earn vacation based on division (a) above.
   (g)   Full-time police officers terminating employment due to voluntary
resignation or retirement shall be paid all earned and unused accumulated
vacation time.
   (h)   In the case of death of any full-time police officer, the earned and
unused accumulated vacation time shall be paid to the employee's estate.
(Ord. 1998-15. Passed 12-15-98; Ord. 2005-1. Passed 1-4-05; Ord. 2010-12.
Passed 5-18-10; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12; Ord. 2013-9. Passed 3-19-13.)
242.14   UNIFORM ALLOWANCES.
   (a)   Effective January 1, 2013, every full-time police officer shall be
entitled to a uniform/maintenance allowance of one thousand one hundred dollars
($1,100.00) in each calendar year payable in such manner as determined from
time to time by the Police Chief, Fiscal Officer and the Mayor.
(Ord. 1996-4. Passed 2-6-96; Ord. 2005-1. Passed 1-4-05.)
   (b)   Effective January 1, 2013 every part-time police officer shall be
entitled to a uniform/maintenance allowance of five hundred fifty dollars
($550.00) in each calendar year, payable in such manner as determined from time
to time by the Police Chief, Fiscal Officer and the Mayor.
   (c)   For the first year of employment, all newly hired police officers
shall be equipped with a police uniform in accordance with their needs as
approved by the Chief of Police.
   (d)   Required police officer leather, equipment and safety items shall be
furnished to each officer by the Village.
   (e)   In the event a police officer does not serve the entire 12 months, the
clothing allowance shall be pro-rated based upon the actual days served in the
year in which their employment was discontinued.
(Ord. 1990-16. Passed 6-5-90; Ord. 2005-1. Passed 1-4-05; Ord. 2006-35. Passed
1-2-07; Ord. 2007-26. Passed 7-3-07; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.141   COMPENSATION TIME.
   No full-time or part-time police officer can carry more than 400 hours of
compensation time from any one calendar year to the next. All compensation time
in excess of 400 hours as of the last day of any year shall be paid to the
police officer in the following January.
(Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.15   HOSPITALIZATION INSURANCE.
   (a)   For full-time officers, the Village shall pay the monthly insurance
premiums necessary to provide medical and prescription coverage, vision
coverage and dental coverage, including orthodontia. Lasik eye surgery up to
one thousand eight hundred dollars ($1,800) per officer will be paid for full-
time and part-time officers, effective January 1, 2008 through December 31,
2012.
   (b)   Effective January 1, 2018, employees are responsible for paying 15% of
the premium for health insurance. Employee contributions will be automatically
deducted from employee paychecks through the Finance Department. Employee
contributions will be split between the first two paychecks of each month.
(Ord. 1996-22. Passed 11-5-96; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2005-1.
Passed 1-4-05; Ord. 2007-26. Passed 7-3-07; Ord. 2007-37. Passed 12-18-07; Ord.
2010-25. Passed 6-15-2010; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12; Ord. 2017-23. Passed
12-19-17.)
242.16   SICK LEAVE AND FUNERAL LEAVE FOR FULL-TIME OFFICERS.
   (a)   Each full-time police officer shall be entitled to sick leave of one
and one-fourth days for each completed month of employment by the Village.
(Ord. 1968-16. Passed 6-18-68; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01.)
   (b)   Unused sick leave for such full-time officers shall be cumulative.
Unused sick leave may be converted by an officer whose employment is terminated
voluntarily or due to the lack of work on the basis of 55% of the accumulated
time.
(Ord. 1998-15. Passed 12-15-98; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2009-28.
Passed 11-10-09.)
   (c)   No sick leave in excess of three consecutive days shall be allowed
unless such officer furnishes evidence satisfactory to the Chief of Police that
the illness complained of is of longer duration. The Mayor and Chief of Police
shall have the right to require a physician's report and/or diagnosis of such
officer's condition at any time.
   (d)   Illness in the immediate family of such officer, requiring the
attention of such officer, shall entitle such officer to two days of sick leave
for each such illness. For purposes of this subsection, "immediate family"
shall be construed to include father, mother, sister, brother, spouse and
child.
(Ord. 1968-16. Passed 6-18-68; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01.)
   (e)   In the event of the death of an officer's spouse, child or parent or
the parent of a spouse, brother, sister, stepfather, stepmother, stepbrother,
stepsister, grandparents, grandchildren and stepchildren, such officer shall be
entitled to three days funeral leave. In the event of the death of an officer's
brother-in-law or sister-in-law, such officer shall be entitled to one day
funeral leave.
(Ord. 1987-7. Passed 1-20-87; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01.)
   (f)   The Clerk shall keep accurate records of accumulated sick leave for
each such officer, as well as reports from physicians and other data pertinent
hereto.
(Ord. 1968-16. Passed 6-18-68; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2007-26.
Passed 7-3-07; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.17   APPROVAL OF TIME RECORDS FOR PART-TIME PATROLMEN.
   Each part-time Patrolman shall keep an itemized and accurate record of time
devoted each day to police duties and snow removal and street maintenance
duties, which record shall be submitted to the Chief of Police and Mayor for
approval, and such part-time Patrolmen shall be paid every two weeks.
(Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.18   GROUP LIFE INSURANCE.
   Each full-time police officer of the Village shall be entitled to group term
life insurance coverage in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) at Village expense, after his or her appointment as such an officer
becomes final. Each part-time police officer of the Village shall be entitled
to group term life insurance coverage in the amount of fifty thousand dollars
($50,000) at Village expense, after his or her appointment as such an officer
becomes final. Upon retirement, each full-time officer shall receive a ten
thousand dollar ($10,000) life insurance policy payable to his or her estate or
beneficiary upon his or her death. The full cost of such coverage shall be paid
by the Village.
(Ord. 1998-15. Passed 12-15-98; Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2007-2;
Passed 1-16-07; Ord. 2012-3. Passed 2-21-12; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.19   ANIMAL WARDEN.
   (a)   An Animal Control Service shall be hired and be appointed by the Mayor
subject to the confirmation of Council. The duties of the Animal Control
Service shall be those as prescribed by the Mayor and the Chief of Police. The
appointment shall be on a contractual basis. The cost of the Animal Control
Service shall be negotiated from time to time and included in the Police
budget.
   (b)   Alternatively, the Chief of Police is authorized to assign animal
control service duties to any auxiliary, part-time or full-time police officer
that has the requisite training, qualifications, and/or certification to
perform in that capacity, and the police officer or officers so assigned shall
be compensated for that service at the same rate as that prescribed for their
police officer position.
(Ord. 1985-7. Passed 2-19-85; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12; Ord. 2014-8.
Passed 9-16-14.)
242.191   K-9 OFFICER.
   (a)   The Village Police Department may implement and maintain a K-9 officer
program at the discretion of the Chief of Police with the approval of the
Mayor/Safety Director, or at the direction of the Mayor/Safety Director. The K-
9 officer shall be selected from the full-time police officers at the sole
discretion of the Chief of Police.
   (b)   The K-9 officer shall be compensated at their regular pay rate. In
addition, the K-9 officer shall be additionally compensated for 1-1/4 hours per
week to cover year round care and maintenance of the K-9. Said compensation
shall be made as income paid, compensatory time, or time off (such as early
departure from shift) at the discretion of the Chief of Police.
(Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.20   JURY DUTY.
   Full-time police officers of the Village, while serving upon a jury in any
court of record, shall be paid their regular salary for the period of time so
served. Time so served upon a jury shall be deemed active service with the
Village for all purposes.
(Ord. 1981-53. Passed 8-25-81; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.21   PAYMENT DURING DISABILITY PERIODS.
   Each regular full-time member of the Police Department who may be disabled
as the result of a traumatic injury suffered in the discharge or performance of
his or her assigned duty in the Department shall be entitled to receive his or
her regular compensation during such period of disability, but in no case for a
longer period than three months. However, any member of the Department making a
claim for compensation as provided in this section shall, at the request of the
Mayor, submit himself or herself to a physical examination by a physician
designated by the Mayor, and if such physician finds that such person is able
to resume his or her official duties such person may be ordered to do so and
the compensation hereby provided for such disability shall forthwith cease.
Further, the compensation provided for in this section in the case of a
service-connected disability shall be exclusive of any sick leave allowance
established in Section
242.16(a) and shall in no way affect the sick leave accumulated in conformity
with Section
242.16(b) and nothing herein contained shall be held to impair or repeal any
ordinance or law concerning the establishment and maintenance of police relief
or pension funds.
   Any qualified full-time officer disabled as a result of negligence, failure
to follow standard safety procedure or failure to wear safety equipment
provided shall waive the right to any claim under this section.
(Ord. 1982-41. Passed 9-2-82; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.22   REIMBURSEMENT FOR EDUCATIONAL COURSES.
   (a)   For all courses required to attain an Associates Degree in Law
Enforcement for Police Department personnel and for such other courses as are
approved by the Mayor and the Police Chief for full-time safety force members,
the Village will reimburse a full-time safety force member for the costs of
such courses, including application, tuition, fees and the cost of books
necessary to complete such courses.
   (b)   The following enumerated conditions and requirements are hereby
established as conditions precedent to the reimbursement for approved
educational courses:
      (1)   Full-time Department members shall have completed one year of
service in the Department before they will be entitled to reimbursement for
approved educational courses under this section.
      (2)   For cost reimbursement, a minimum grade of C or its equivalent is
required.
      (3)   Reimbursement will be paid only upon the completion of the approved
courses and upon submission, to the satisfaction of the Mayor and the Chief, of
the school transcript or other competent evidence that the courses were
successfully completed.
      (4)   Receipts for tuition, fees and the cost of books and related
materials necessary for course completion shall be presented and documented
before payment.
      (5)   Courses and subjects taken shall not interfere with scheduled duty
assignments.
(Ord. 1983-39. Passed 10-4-83; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.23   OVERTIME SCHEDULING.
   Full-time police officers shall have first choice to select unscheduled days
not regularly assigned by the scheduling authority. Selection will be in
accordance with Departmental seniority rights and the rules established by the
Chief of Police who has the responsibility of duty scheduling.
(Ord. 1985-7. Passed 2-19-85; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.24   LOSS OF SENIORITY RIGHTS.
   Any employee who resigns or is discharged shall forfeit all seniority rights
which he or she has earned and to which he or she has been entitled.
(Ord. 1985-7. Passed 2-19-85; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.25   HEALTH CLUB MEMBERSHIP.
   The Village shall pay up to one hundred dollars ($100.00) towards a
membership in a health club for a full-time police officer. Such membership is
subject to the approval of the Mayor upon the presentation of an acceptable
paid receipt reflecting the effective dates and type of membership.
(Ord. 1985-7. Passed 2-19-85; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.26   NONRESIDENT SERVICE.
   (a)   The Police Department is hereby authorized to provide police
protection to any county, municipal corporation or township without a contract,
upon the authorization of the Chief of Police or the Mayor, pursuant to Ohio
R.C. 737.041.
   (b)   Police Department members acting outside the Village limits, pursuant
to this section, shall be entitled to participate in any pension or indemnity
fund established by the Village or the State to the same extent as while acting
within the Village limits, and are also entitled to other benefits provided by
law.
(Res. 1989-4. Passed 1-17-89; Ord. 2012-23. Passed 10-16-12.)
242.27   RANK DIFFERENTIAL.
   (a)   A 10% rank differential shall exist between the rank base pay of
Patrol Officer and rank base pay of Sergeant.
   (b)   A 5% rank differential shall exist between the rank base pay of
Sergeant and rank base pay of Lieutenant.
   (c)   A 5% rank differential shall exist between the rank base pay of
Lieutenant and rank base pay of Captain.
(Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2007-26. Passed 7-3-07; Ord. 2012-23.
Passed 10-16- 12.)
242.28   STATE QUALIFICATIONS BONUS (WEAPONS RECERTIFICATION).
   Full-time and part-time police officers who pass all required components of
the State mandated annual weapons recertification course on their first attempt
shall receive a four hundred fifty dollar ($450.00) State Qualifications Bonus.
Police officers shall be eligible for this bonus once each calendar year.
(Ord. 2001-20. Passed 12-18-01; Ord. 2007-26. Passed 7-3-07; Ord. 2012-23.
Passed 10-16-12.)
242.29   AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT.
   (a)   There is hereby established an Auxiliary Police Unit within the Police
Department which consists of one Auxiliary Police Sergeant and up to eight
Auxiliary Police Officers. The Police Chief shall appoint the members of the
Auxiliary Police Unit, including the designation for the Auxiliary Police
Sergeant, and the Police Chief shall be the executive head of the Auxiliary
Police Unit.
   (b)   The Police Chief, or their designee, shall be responsible for
scheduling and the work assignments to members of the Auxiliary Police Unit.
   (c)   Members of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall follow all classified
orders of the Police Department, and shall be under the immediate authority of
the Police Department shift supervisor.
   (d)   Members of the Auxiliary Police Unit shall only wear their Auxiliary
Police Unit uniform during the time they are working as an Auxiliary Police
Officer for the Village, including to and from their work shift.
   (e)   Auxiliary Police Officers shall be compensated pursuant to
Chapter 260 of these Codified Ordinances. They are not eligible to participate
in the Police and Fireman's Disability and Pension Fund; shall not be in the
classified service of the Village; and shall participate in the Ohio Public
Employees Retirement System.
   (f)   Auxiliary Police Officers shall not work in place of or perform the
same assigned duties of regular Police Officers of the Police Department.
(Ord. 2013-6. Passed 2-19-13.)
CHAPTER 244
Fire Protection
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Village contracts for fire protection services with
numerous cities and villages in the area. Copies of the latest relevant
agreements may be obtained, at cost, from the Village Clerk.

Chapter 244. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross
references and any future legislation.

   EDITOR'S NOTE: Provisions relating to the Department of Buildings are

CHAPTER 248
Recreation Department

248.02   Assistant Recreation Director.

248.05   Work week of Department personnel; compensation.

248.01   APPOINTMENT OF RECREATION DIRECTOR.
   There is hereby established, in and for the Village, the office of
Recreation Director of the Village to direct and supervise recreation in the
Village. Such Director shall be appointed by the Mayor for a period of one year
only, subject to confirmation by Council and subject to the provisions of
Section
248.07.
(Ord. 1978-17. Passed 4-4-78.)
248.02   ASSISTANT RECREATION DIRECTOR.
   There is hereby established the office of Assistant Recreation Director to
assist the Recreation Director in the recreation program. Such Assistant shall
be selected by the Mayor and the Director, subject to the provisions of Section
248.07.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.03   PLAYGROUND AIDES.
   The Mayor and the Recreation Director are hereby authorized to appoint, with
the approval of the Recreation Committee of Council, as many playground aides
as they may deem necessary or advisable for the successful operation of a
recreation program, subject to the provisions of Section
248.07.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.04   ORGANIZATION OF RECREATION PROGRAM.
   The recreation program shall be organized and directed by the Recreation
Director, under the supervision of the Mayor. The program shall provide
supervised recreation for all school age children and adults of the Village.
Normally during the summer program, the Recreation Center shall be staffed from
10:00 a. m. to 9:00 p. m., five days a week, with staffing over weekends at the
Director's discretion. Any program for children seven years of age or younger
shall be in cooperation with an adult who shall accompany the children.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.05   WORK WEEK OF DEPARTMENT PERSONNEL; COMPENSATION.
   The Recreation Director, the Assistant Recreation Director and playground
aides shall be employed full-time only as long as interest and attendance
justify their employment. The hourly compensation to be paid for such
employment shall be as determined from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.06   COMPENSATION PERIOD.
   The compensation of Recreation Department personnel shall be paid upon
submission to the Mayor for his or her prior approval of itemized statements of
hours spent and work performed.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.07   APPOINTMENT AND HIRING OF ASSISTANT DIRECTOR AND PLAYGROUND AIDES.
   The Assistant Recreation Director and playground aides may be appointed and
hired for the purpose of assisting the Recreation Director in planning and
organizing a recreation program, preparing and maintaining the recreational
facilities used therein and, in general, performing such tasks as are pertinent
and desirable for the successful operation of a recreation program. Such
appointments or hirings shall be for one year.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.08   DUTIES OF RECREATION DIRECTOR.
   The Recreation Director shall have charge of all recreation personnel and be
responsible for the enforcement of Recreation Center rules; shall supervise
purchasing of required material for the recreation program, including arts and
crafts, sports, etc., made through Village purchase regulations; shall be
responsible for keeping accurate time records and shall sign personnel time
sheets presented to the Mayor for approval and subsequent payment; shall be
responsible for publicity for the program, including distribution of the
program schedule, through the local news media; shall prepare an inventory of
equipment at the end of the summer program and shall prepare a summary of the
program with comments and recommendations.
(Ord. 1984-11. Passed 5-1-84.)
248.09   BASEBALL COMMISSIONER.
   There is hereby established the part-time position of Baseball Commissioner,
who shall be employed at the will of the Recreation Director and Mayor,
annually, and who shall act in that capacity no earlier than March 1st of any
year and no later than September 30th of any year, as directed by the
Recreation Director and the Mayor. Said Baseball Commissioner shall act under
the direction, guidance and supervision of the Recreation Director, and shall
facilitate, direct, and oversee the Village baseball program.
(Ord. 2005-13. Passed 4-19-05.)
