1630.01   POSTING ARSON LAWS.
   The owner, operator or lessee of any transient residential building shall
post the provisions of Ohio R.C. 2909.02 and 2909.03 in a conspicuous place in
each room occupied by guests in such building. The owner, operator or lessee of
any nontransient residential building, institution, school or place of assembly
shall post the provisions of such sections in conspicuous places upon such
premises.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.02   SETTING FIRES WHICH SPREAD.
   No person shall set, kindle or cause to be set or kindled any fire which,
through his or her negligence, spreads beyond its immediate confines to any
structure, field or wood lot.
(ORC 3737.62) (Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.03   RESPONSIBILITIES UPON DISCOVERY OF UNFRIENDLY FIRES.
   (a)   The owner, operator or lessee, an employee of any owner, operator or
lessee, an occupant, and any person in direct control of any building regulated
under the Ohio Building Code, upon the discovery of an unfriendly fire or upon
receiving information that there is an unfriendly fire on the premises, shall
immediately and with all reasonable dispatch and diligence call or otherwise
notify the Fire Department concerning the fire and shall spread an alarm
immediately to all occupants of the building.
   (b)   For the purposes of this section, "unfriendly fire" means a fire of a
destructive nature as distinguished from a controlled fire intended for a
beneficial purpose.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.04   SALE AND USE OF FIRE EQUIPMENT; STANDARDS; SERVICE AND REPAIR OF
EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   No person shall sell, offer for sale, or use any fire protection or
fire-fighting equipment that does not meet the minimum standards established by
the Ohio Fire Marshal in the Ohio Fire Code.
   (b)   Except for public and private mobile fire trucks, no person shall
service, test, repair or install for profit any fire protection or fire-
fighting equipment without a certificate issued by the Ohio Fire Marshal.
(ORC 3737.65) (Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.05   MISCELLANEOUS STORAGE.
   (a)   No person shall establish or maintain a new bulk plant for flammable
liquids in the Village.
   (b)   No person shall establish a new bulk liquefied petroleum gas plant in
the Village.
   (c)   No person shall store explosives or blasting agents in the Village.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.06   FIRE LANES.
   The Fire Safety Officer shall inspect all multiple dwellings, retail,
commercial, public and industrial buildings, private alleys and off-street
parking areas to determine and establish fire lanes within or about such areas.
The Fire Safety Officer shall notify the owner or occupant of such places of
the areas which he or she has designated as fire lanes, and such owner or
occupant shall mark and post such fire lanes with markings and signs as
approved by the Fire Safety Officer. No vehicle shall stop or park in such fire
lanes except for loading or unloading of merchandise at places designated by
the Fire Safety Officer, or for the momentary discharge or pickup of
passengers.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.07   OBSTRUCTING ESCAPES, EXITS AND HYDRANTS; FIRE DOORS.
   (a)   No person shall encumber or obstruct any fire escape or emergency
exit, or in any manner tamper with any fire door or emergency exit, in such
manner as to hinder or prevent the immediate use of the same in the event of
fire or other emergency.
   (b)   No person shall obstruct the access to any fire hydrant, or place or
allow to be placed any obstruction in front thereof, between the curb line and
the center of the street, or within ten feet from each side of any such
hydrant, or stand or park any machine or vehicle within ten feet from each side
of any such hydrant, or within twenty feet from each side of the vehicle exit
of any fire station.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.08   SPRINKLER SYSTEMS.
   (a)   A limited area sprinkler system of any approved type shall be
installed in storage and workshop areas in all portions of use group "A"
(Assembly), "B" (Business), "I" (Institutional), "M" (Mercantile) or "RI" and
"R2" (Residential hotels and multifamily) occupied for storage, workshop, scrub
room or similar purposes. (References are to Ohio Building Code.)
   (b)   In all storage areas where a domestic water supply is used to supply
the automatic sprinkler system and where more than four sprinkler heads are
installed, a water flow valve along with a visual audible device installed per
the specifications of the Fire Prevention Bureau. Where more than 19 heads are
supplied off of one supply line, either a domestic water supply line or a fire
line, the system shall be monitored by an approved alarm monitoring service.
   (c)   In reference to division (a) of this section, a variance may be
granted by the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief, to install a
monitored automatic fire detection system throughout the building in lieu of a
sprinkler system. Division (b) of this section shall apply if an outside horn/
strobe unit or monitoring by an approved alarm monitoring service.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.09   PROPANE STORAGE.
   (a)   There shall be no storage of propane permitted in areas other than
those zoned industrial in excess of 100 pounds, except as specified elsewhere
in this section. A permit shall be obtained from the Fire Prevention Officer or
Fire Chief before any storage or use of propane is allowed in the Village. An
exception is allowed for 20 pounds of propane for residential gas grills.
   (b)   Any propane-fired roofing equipment, regardless of size, shall be
required to have a permit issued for it by the Fire Department prior to work
being started.
   (c)   Propane for industrial use shall be stored only in an approved manner
and area.
   (d)   A permit is required for the storage, sale or exchange of filled
propane tanks in areas zoned Business District. The storage of tanks shall
comply with the following:
      (1)   Tanks are limited to a maximum size of 20 pounds each. The total
number of tanks either full, partially full or empty is limited to 18. In areas
where tanks can be stored in locations not accessible to public vehicle traffic
and a minimum of 200 feet from an adjoining residential property, or an
adjoining property occupied by a school, church, hospital, athletic field or
other point of public gathering, the total number of tanks can be increased to
54.
      (2)   All tanks shall be stored in an approved racking system. Racks will
only be allowed against non-combustible walls. Racks shall be a minimum of 20
feet from any wall opening, exit or fueling dispensing pump. All racks shall
have approved crash protection. The installation and location of all propane
storage racks shall be approved by the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire
Chief.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.10   POSTING OF OCCUPANCY LOADS.
   The Village Fire Safety Officer along with the Village Building Inspector
shall have the authority to post all occupancy loads, using the guidelines
outlined in Rule 10 of the Ohio Fire Code. The Building Inspector and the
Village Fire Safety Officer shall concur before any posting of occupancy loads.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.11   HAZARDOUS OR DANGEROUS MATERIALS.
   (a)   Hazardous or dangerous materials shall be stored, used and transported
only in a safe manner as set forth in the Code of Federal Regulations Sections
49 through 100, the Ohio Fire Code or NFPA Standards. A permit must be secured
from the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief for the use, storage and
handling of hazardous or dangerous materials.
   (b)   When it is determined by the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief
that a location in the Village has on its premises any extremely hazardous
substance, as listed by the local emergency planning committee, the key box
provided for in Section
1630.12 shall be large enough to contain the emergency plan of the facility, a
listing of the location of the substance, names of individuals to be contacted,
the impact upon the environment and the community of such substance, and any
other information that the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief may
require.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.12   KEY BOXES.
   (a)   When access to or within a structure or area is unduly difficult
because of secured openings or where immediate access is necessary for life-
saving or firefighting purposes, the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief
may require a key box be installed in an accessible location. The key box shall
be a type approved by the Fire Prevention Officer or Fire Chief and shall
contain keys to gain necessary access as required.
   (b)   The key box shall be installed in all newly constructed buildings,
other than the Country Home District, immediately after the adoption of this
section, and shall be installed on all existing locations upon change of
ownership or occupant.
   (c)   A firefighter's recall key for elevators shall be made available to
the Fire Division at a location specified by the Village Fire Safety Officer or
Fire Chief. A key box may be required.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
1630.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both, for each
offense.
   (b)   Each day during or on which a violation of any of the provisions of
this chapter occurs or continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 2008-25. Passed 6-3-08.)
CHAPTER 1640
Elevators
1640.01   Application; purpose; conflict of laws.
1640.02   General requirements.
 
1640.99   Penalty
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Power to regulate elevators - see Ohio R.C. 715.26
   Division of Elevator Inspection - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 4105
   Elevator companies - see Ohio R.C. 1743.08
   Elevators for freestanding surgical outpatient facilities - see B.R. & T.
826.13
   Elevator permit fees - see B. & H.
1442.04(r)
   Ohio Fire Code - see F.P. Ch.
1610
   National Fire Code - see F.P. Ch.
1620
1640.01   APPLICATION; PURPOSE; CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   This chapter shall apply to all buildings built subsequent to April 1, 1973.
The purpose of this chapter is to provide regulations that supplement the
provisions of the Ohio Fire Code and the National Fire Code relating to
elevators. Where this chapter is more restrictive in its intention than such
Codes, this chapter shall control.
(Ord. 2003-6. Passed 4-1-03.)
1640.02   GENERAL REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Any building in which elevators are installed shall have at least one
elevator of minimum capacity of 2,500 pounds. Platform size, door size and
location shall be suitably arranged to accept a stretcher twenty-three inches
wide by six feet, five inches long without tipping, lifting or other abnormal
movement. An elevator car with a clear inside dimension of six feet, eight
inches wide by four feet, three inches front to back with single slide doors of
two feet, ten inches or more in width will meet this requirement.
   (b)   One elevator in every building which shall be designated by the Fire
Safety Officer or Fire Chief shall be equipped with a key lock switch on the
ground floor to remove such elevator from automatic service and return it to
the ground level immediately for manual operation by the Fire Department.
   (c)   A key-operated lock switch shall be provided adjacent to the elevator
at the street floor landing and at other landings subject to the discretion of
the Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief.
   (d)   The key-operated lock switch shall, when operated, cancel existing car
calls, prevent registrations of further car calls, prevent the opening of the
elevator doors except at the landing at which the switch is located and cause
the cab to travel to that landing, bypassing other landing calls.
   (e)   When the elevator car arrives at the firefighter's landing, the doors
shall open and remain open until they are closed by the operator of the
elevator from the car.
   (f)   The key lock switch to be used both in the elevator car and at the
various floor levels as may be specified shall be manufactured by the Chicago
Lock Co., lock model number 2174-2 and key number C2136, or equivalent.
   (g)   (1)   All elevators equipped with photoelectric tube devices, which
control the closing of automatic, power-operated elevator doors, shall have a
switch located in the elevator car which, when actuated, will render the
photoelectric tube device ineffective.
      (2)   This switch shall be of the constant pressure type, requiring not
less than ten pounds nor more than fifteen pounds of pressure to actuate. It
shall be located not less than six feet nor more than six feet, six inches
above the car floor and shall be in or adjacent to the operating panel. The
switch shall be clearly labeled "Emergency Switch to Close Doors."
   (h)   Each elevator cab shall have an emergency light to provide adequate
light within the elevator car when the primary power fails.
   (i)   Each elevator cab shall be equipped with an emergency bell actuated by
an emergency switch inside the cab, which shall be supplied with a source of
emergency power so the bell may be actuated when the primary power fails.
(Ord. 2003-6. Passed 4-1-03.)
1640.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of ths
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months,
or both, for each offense.
   (b)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2003-6. Passed 4-1-03.)
CHAPTER 1650
Smoke Detectors
1650.01   Definitions.
1650.02   Installation required; placement; devices for hearing impaired
persons; hard-wired detectors.
1650.03   Testing and inspections.
1650.04   Tampering.
1650.05   Enforcement; refusal of inspections; installation orders.
1650.06   Compliance.
 
1650.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Smoke detectors - see B. & H. Ch.
1488
   Ohio Fire Code - see F.P. Ch.
1610
   National Fire Code - see F.P. Ch.
1620
1650.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Fire detection device" means equipment that automatically detects
heat, flame, products of combustion, flammable gases, or other conditions
likely to produce fire or explosion and cause other automatic actuation of
alarm and protection equipment.
   (b)   "Hard-wired" means directly connected to the electrical power supply
of the building, the power source of which is required for smoke detectors.
   (c)   "Hearing impaired" means a hearing problem impairing the ability of a
person to be awakened by a standard smoke detector, whether or not such person
is wearing a hearing aid.
   (d)   "Occupant" means a person over one year of age, living, sleeping,
cooking or eating in, or having actual possession of, a dwelling unit or room
used for room occupancy.
   (e)   "Owner" means the owner or owners of the premises, a vendee in
possession, a mortgagee or receiver in possession, a lessee or joint lessee of
the whole thereof, or an agent or any other person, firm, or corporation
directly in control of the premises or having a legal or equitable interest in
the property.
   (f)   "Sleeping area" means an area of a dwelling containing bedrooms which
are separated from each other by no use area other than a bathroom.
   (g)   "Smoke detector" means an approved device which detects visible or
invisible particles of combustion and which emits an audible signal indicating
a fire condition or both an audible and a visual signal indicating a fire
condition.
   (h)   "Wireless transmitting smoke detectors" means an approved wireless
device which detects visible or invisible particles of combustion and which
emits an audible signal indicating a fire condition and cause the automatic
actuation of a fire alarm system. Said units shall be UL listed and meet the
requirements of National Fire Protection Association 72.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
1650.02   INSTALLATION REQUIRED; PLACEMENT; DEVICES FOR HEARING IMPAIRED
PERSONS; HARD-WIRED DETECTORS.
   (a)   Owners of all dwellings shall install a minimum of one smoke detector
adjacent to the sleeping area in each dwelling unit. At least one additional
smoke detector shall be installed on each additional story of the dwelling,
including the basement, but excluding any crawl space or unfinished attic. For
dwellings or with one or more split levels, a smoke detector on an upper level
shall suffice for an adjacent lower level, provided that the lower level is
less than one full story below the upper level. If a door intervenes between
adjacent levels, a smoke detector shall be installed on both levels. Smoke
detectors shall be listed with an approved testing agency and shall be
installed in a manner and location consistent with the manufacturer's
instructions. Where a dwelling is occupied by a person who is deaf or hearing
impaired, and a written request for the installation of a smoke detector is
received by the owner from an occupant in the dwelling, a smoke detector shall
be installed by the owner which provides a visual or vibrating signal
sufficient to warn the deaf or hearing impaired individual when activated.
   (b)   Hard-wired smoke detectors, with battery backup, shall be installed in
any new construction of all dwellings. Wiring shall be permanent and without a
disconnection switch, other than those required for overcurrent protection.
Battery-operated smoke detectors may be installed in existing dwellings. All
smoke detectors shall be listed with an approved testing agency. When
alterations, repairs or additions requiring a permit occur, or when one or more
sleeping rooms are added or created in an existing dwelling, hard-wired smoke
detectors, with battery backup, shall be installed in the entire building, if
it is deemed necessary by a building inspector or a fire official. No smoke
detector shall be hard-wired, with battery backup, unless plans for
installation have been submitted to, and reviewed by, the Village Fire Safety
Officer or Fire Chief and an electrical permit has been obtained from the
Building Department.
   (c)   In all use groups that are required to have an approved fire alarm or
fire detection system, and have more than 19 activation devices, then said
system shall be monitored by an approved alarm monitoring service.
   (d)   Any building with a fire alarm or fire detection system may be
required to have an annunciating panel(s) in locations as directed by the
Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
1650.03   TESTING AND INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   Testing of hard-wired smoke detectors, with battery backup, shall be
done by the occupant not less than once a month. Testing of battery-operated
smoke detectors shall be done by the occupant not less than once a week.
   (b)   At every change of occupancy dwelling and multifamily or incidental
to, a sale, lease or sublease of such dwelling, it shall be the duty of the
owner to inspect the smoke detectors to ensure proper working condition. This
division shall not be construed to vitiate or render void any contract, lease
or sublease subject thereto.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
1650.04   TAMPERING.
   No person shall tamper or interfere with the effectiveness of a smoke
detector and/or any fire alarm or fire detection system.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
1650.05   ENFORCEMENT; REFUSAL OF INSPECTIONS; INSTALLATION ORDERS.
   (a)   The Building Commissioner shall have concurrent jurisdiction with the
Fire Prevention Officer or the Fire Chief to inspect the installation of any
smoke detector required pursuant to Section
1650.02. If, upon inspection, a violation of Section
1650.02 is found, the inspector shall issue a written notice of such violation
to the owner requiring the owner to conform to Section
1650.02 within 30 calendar days of receipt of such notice.
   (b)   No owner shall refuse to allow inspection at reasonable times of
dwellings by a duly authorized Village inspector.
   (c)   After investigating a fire in a dwelling that does not contain a smoke
detector, the Village's investigating authority shall issue to the owner a
smoke detection installation order. Failure to comply with such an order within
15 calendar days of re-occupancy of the premises constitutes a violation of
this chapter.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
1650.06   COMPLIANCE.
   It shall be the responsibility of the owner of a dwelling to bring and keep
such dwelling in compliance with this chapter.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
1650.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) and imprisoned no more than six months.
   (b)   Each day a violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate
offense.
(Ord. 2008-26. Passed 6-3-08.)
CHAPTER 1660
Carbon Monoxide Detectors
1660.01   Definitions.
1660.02   Installation required; placement; hard-wired detectors.
 
1660.99   Penalty.
1660.01   DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Hard-wired" means directly connected to the electrical power supply
of the building, the power source of which is required for carbon monoxide
detectors.
   (b)   "Sleeping area" means an area of a dwelling containing bedrooms which
are separated from each other by no use area other than a bathroom.
(Ord. 2003-6. Passed 4-1-03.)
1660.02   INSTALLATION REQUIRED; PLACEMENT; HARD-WIRED DETECTORS.
   At least one carbon monoxide detector shall be installed in all new
residential constructions, outside the sleeping area, in accordance with
manufacturer's recommendations. The carbon monoxide detector shall be hard-
wired, with battery backup, and shall meet Underwriter's Laboratory standards,
that is UL 2034.
(Ord. 2003-6. Passed 4-1-03.)
1660.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter is guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than one thousand
dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months, or both, for each
offense.
   (b)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2003-6. Passed 4-1-03.)
CHAPTER 1670
Storage Tanks
1670.01   Inspection of underground tanks and inventory records for underground
storage of flammable liquids.
1670.02   Abandoned underground tanks.
1670.03   New occupancies.
1670.04   Records.
1670.05   Costs; corrections.
1670.06   Installation instructions.
1670.07   Interior coating and repair.
1670.08   Above-ground tanks.
 
1670.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Gasoline service stations - see B.R. & T. Ch.
832
1670.01   INSPECTION OF UNDERGROUND TANKS AND INVENTORY RECORDS FOR UNDERGROUND
STORAGE OF FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS.
   (a)   Ohio Administrative Code Emergency Rule Section 1301:7-9-15 authorizes
the State Fire Marshal to delegate local certified fire inspectors the
authority to conduct inspections of underground storage tanks for compliance
with recently enacted State regulations concerning installations, repairs and
upgrades. Accordingly, the Fire Department is hereby delegated the authority to
perform such inspections, and, further, is authorized to obtain permission from
the State Fire Marshal for authority to issue delegated underground storage
tank permits. Such permits shall be issued in lieu of the permits required to
be obtained from the State Fire Marshal by the owners and operators of
underground storage tanks.
   (b)   Ohio Administrative Code Sections 1301:7-9-06, -07 and -08 are hereby
incorporated by reference, and all property owners within the Village must be
in compliance therewith.
   (c)   The operator of oil-burning equipment shall make an inventory of the
underground tanks at least once every seven days for the purpose of checking
whether or not there is any loss or accumulation of water.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.02   ABANDONED UNDERGROUND TANKS.
   Any abandoned or not in use underground tank must be removed from the ground
within a period not to exceed 90 days. All piping shall also be removed from
the ground at the same time the tanks are removed. All tanks and piping shall
be removed in a manner that meets the safety standards of the Village Fire
Safety Officer.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.03   NEW OCCUPANCIES.
   New occupancies (change of ownership or change of lease) shall have a
hydrostatic test and adequate inventory records before any permit is issued. A
copy of such test and inventories shall be received by the Village Fire Safety
Officer and, if there are no leaking conditions, a permit may be issued at that
time.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.04   RECORDS.
   Any leaking condition, shortage of flammable and combustible liquids or
spill into public sewers, drains and waterways shall be reported at once to the
Fire Department. Procedures for locating and testing for underground leaks
shall be as outlined in NFPA Pamphlet No. 329, "Undergound Leakage of Flammable
and Combustible Liquids". Storage tank inventory records for 30 days prior to
closing shall be made available to the Village Fire Safety Officer prior to the
closing of a station.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.05   COSTS; CORRECTIONS.
   Costs incurred by the Village which may entail Village fire safety
personnel, or their designated assistants, or supplies, equipment or work that
may be ordered by the Village Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief, shall be the
responsibility of the owner of the tanks. Corrections shall be made as soon as
possible to protect life and property.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.06   INSTALLATION INSTRUCTIONS.
   Underground storage tanks shall bear a UL label and be in conformity with
Underwriter's Laboratories. In addition:
   (a)   Installation of storage tanks shall be in accordance with the
manufacturer's specifications.
   (b)   A copy of the manufacturer's installation instructions/specifications
shall be provided to the Fire Safety Officer or Fire Chief.
   (c)   All storage tanks shall be anchored. Anchoring shall be in accordance
with the manufacturer's specifications.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.07   INTERIOR COATING AND REPAIR.
   The interior coating and repair of leaking and/or deteriorated underground
liquid petroleum tanks shall be in accordance with the manufacturer's
specifications.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.08   ABOVE-GROUND TANKS.
   (a)   A temporary installation of an above-ground storage tank, not to
exceed 500 gallons capacity, for flammable, combustible or hazardous liquids,
may be permitted by special permit from the Fire Department. The temporary tank
must meet NFPA 30 requirements. The temporary tank permit is good for a maximum
of 60 days, and extensions may be granted by the Village Fire Safety Officer or
Fire Chief for a time period to be determined by the Village Fire Safety
Officer of Fire Chief.
   (b)   A property owner may apply for a permit to permanently install an
above-ground storage tank for flammable, combustible or hazardous liquids. The
application for a permanent tank must be made to the Planning Commission, and
plans must comply with the following requirements of the Fire Department and
the Building Department:
      (1)   Only vaulted tanks are permitted;
      (2)   The tank must meet or exceed NFPA 30, 30A, 31 and 70 requirements;
      (3)   The tank must meet or exceed UL 2085 requirements;
      (4)   The Village Fire Safety Officer will determine the type of crash
protection required individually by site;
      (5)   Vaulted tanks must have interstitial space leak detection with
audible and visual alert;
      (6)   The tank area is to be surrounded by screening or fencing that has
been approved by both the Building and Fire Department. Approved crash
protection shall be installed in all areas with motor vehicle access. No drains
are permitted in the enclosure;
      (7)   The above-ground storage tank owner shall provide the Fire
Department with enough foam to fight a fire involved with the tank. The amount
and type of foam is to be specified by the Fire Department;
      (8)   The tank must be installed on concrete pads only as specified by
the Building Department;
      (9)   The proposed site must be approved by the Fire Department;
      (10)   The anchoring of the tank is required as specified by the
manufacturer;
      (11)   Permanent above-ground fuel tanks are only allowed in an
industrial zoned district;
      (12)   In an industrial zoned district, permanent above-ground tanks not
in excess of 2,000 gallons may only be installed with a minimum buffer area of
200 feet from the boundary of any residential area;
      (13)   In an industrial zoned district, permanent above-ground tanks in
excess of 2,000 gallons, but less than 12,000 gallons, require a minimum buffer
area of 200 feet plus an additional 50 feet for every 1,000 gallons over 2,000
gallons from the boundary of any residential area;
      (14)   For permanent above-ground tanks with a capacity of more than
2,000 gallons, but not more than 12,000 gallons, only diesel fuel or liquid
with a flash-point equal to or greater than that of diesel fuel may be stored.
There shall be no above-ground storage of gasoline.
      (15)   For purposes of this section, the term “residential area” shall
refer to the shortest distance between the storage tank in question and the
closest residential lot line.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
1670.99   PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000) or imprisoned not more than six months,
or both, for each offense.
   (b)   A separate offense shall be deemed committed each day during or on
which a violation or noncompliance occurs or continues.
(Ord. 2008-27. Passed 6-3-08.)
CHAPTER 1680
International Fuel Gas Code
1680.01   Adoption.
1680.01   ADOPTION.
   The 2006 Edition of the International Fuel Gas Code, a copy of which is
available for reference in the office of the Building and Zoning Inspector of
the Village of Walton Hills, Ohio, be and is hereby adopted as the fuel gas
code for the Village of Walton Hills, Ohio.
(Ord. 2008-29. Passed 6-3-08.)
